author: ClimateAudit
text: @AriJLaaksonen @MVirtanen @OlaVaittinen @mikarantane @myytinkertojat I don't urge you to pay attention to "blog science" in general, but you would be incorrect to dismiss my observations on technical details of proxy reconstructions because they are on social media.   I know the topic in great detail.

author: ClimateAudit
text: @AriJLaaksonen @MVirtanen @mikarantane @myytinkertojat so I have some considerable personal experience with garbage versions of data provided by prominent climate scientists. The proxy data archived by Osman et al was archived in a nc format which, when read in ncdf4 in R, yielded garbage results.

author: ClimateAudit
text: @MVirtanen @mikarantane @myytinkertojat their Siple Dome melt frequency series also garbage - see https://t.co/jwI3MI87ca. Rather than using well understood isotope series which didn't yield HS, they introduced a bunch of garbage series and Antarctic HS depends on the garbage, not isotope series.

author: ClimateAudit
text: @MVirtanen @mikarantane @myytinkertojat some more issues discussed here https://t.co/53INld3hVb for WAIS borehole inversion, they chopped off the top of the hole (all layers dated post1960) since annual cycle impacts temperature. Then purported to reconstruct post-1960 temperature from portions of layers dated earlier

author: ClimateAudit
text:
@MVirtanen @mikarantane @myytinkertojat here's another thread discussing issue with borehole inversions of very smooth downhole temperature data, noting older CA article on Truncated SVD and Borehole Inversions on fairly elementary math problems ignored by climatists
https://t.co/uAnxmFBvDT

author: ClimateAudit
text: @MVirtanen @mikarantane @myytinkertojat the borehole temperature inversion data is highly questionable anyway and IMO should not be used in important scientific report. They are inconsistent with isotope data.

author: WEschenbach
WEschenbach
text:
@tan123 Tom, this study is bogus. There's no actual observational data involved. It's either climate model output or reanalysis climate model output. The problem is the real climate is heavily damped, but with climate models often the input makes it through to the output.

w.

author: WEschenbach
text:
@RealArthurDent Another variable is shade. Over decades a tree may get progressively shaded, leading to narrower rings which may get interpreted as colder weather when it's nothing of the sort.

w.

author: WEschenbach
WEschenbach
text: Also, you are using ex-post criteria to select your tree-ring proxies, based on how well they match the modern temperature rise. Unfortunately, this method is well-known to mine for hockey-stick shaped results when used with red noise ...

author: WEschenbach
text: The ring width is determined at a minimum by two inverted-u-shaped relationships‚Äîtemperature and moisture. Either too little or too much of either one will lead to narrow rings. Please explain how you've determined for each ring which side of the humps it's on ... https://t.co/fp5yRlO9Yc

author: WEschenbach
text:
@crentsch @ThijssenR Mmm ... the temperature at the tropical tropopause is on the order of 195K, 17 km up. So that cloud top is either at about 14 km (troposphere) or 21 km (stratosphere, highly unlikely). Since it's in the troposphere, why would the radiation be from the stratosphere?

w.

author: WEschenbach
text:
As a result, asking Lancet for an estimate of PM2.5 "premature deaths" is like asking your barber if you need a haircut ... we can guess the answer in advance.

Should we act to reduce air pollution? In some cities, yes. But it's not some huge worldwide problem as you imply.

w.

author: WEschenbach
text: TL;DR version? Air pollution is a risk. However, we don't know how big. No death certificates show "air pollution" as a cause. The methods they've used for estimating the effects are very sketchy. And Lancet has an axe to grind here‚Äîif there's no problem, there's no publicity.

author: WEschenbach
text:
"At the city level, compliance with WHO air pollution guidelines could prevent between 0 and 138 deaths per 100,000 population".

So for a city of say five million, their estimate is that pollution guideline compliance could prevent 6,900 premature deaths ... or none at all.

author: WEschenbach
text:
"Could be" means that they might or might not be. And can we get vaguer than "a considerable proportion"? 

They also are using "exposure response functions (ERFs) from several studies quantifying the strength of association between air pollution exposure and mortality."

author: WEschenbach
text:
So we're left with statements like this:

"Our results indicate that a considerable proportion of premature deaths in European cities could be avoided annually by lowering air pollution levels."

author: WEschenbach
text:
Next, there is NO WAY to determine if someone in say sub-Saharan Africa died at 60 from malnutrition, a lifetime of repeated malarial infections, or pollution.

And there are NO death certificates that give "air pollution" as the cause of death.

https://t.co/LXPCb0lgmV

author: WEschenbach
text: David, you reference the Lancet study, which does NOT say pollution "kills ten million a year" worldwide. That's a lie. It says "premature deaths", which are defined as deaths at younger than 75 years. And that covers ... well ... about half or more of all deaths worldwide. https://t.co/LF5UJ9Ejzm

author: WEschenbach
text:
@flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl "Project proposal"? That's fantasy world. It is used all the time in the oil industry. There's a word for the situation where it takes you more energy to get the oil out of the ground than you get from the oil. It's called "uneconomical", and that metric is used constantly.

w.

author: WEschenbach
text:
@flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl As I said, you don't understand EROEI. It compares the amount of energy you get with the amount of energy it takes to EXTRACT it. Not the amount of energy that was captured. The energy to extract it. It's why hydrogen is not an energy source.

w.

text:

author: WEschenbach
text: @flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl 3/ The same is true with batteries. You need 90 kg of batteries to equal 1 kg of diesel fuel, so for a big truck, you'll waste untold energy hauling giant batteries up and down the Rockies and elsewhere.

author: WEschenbach
text: @flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl 2/ A problem with ammonia, as with batteries, is energy density/kg. Bunker C (ship fuel) has twice the energy per kg as ammonia, so you'll waste huge amounts of energy just moving the extra fuel, and you'll reduce ship payload.

author: WEschenbach
text: @flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl 1/ Green NH3 is NOT an energy source, just a way to transport energy.  By most estimates, green ammonia will cost two to four times as much to make as conventional ammonia. And ammonia-burning engines are still experimental.

author: WEschenbach
WEschenbach
text:
@flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl 1/ Not True. From the web site:

"Here we take primary energy based on the ‚Äòsubstitution method‚Äô for energy accounting. A quick summary of it is that this accounting method tries to account for the energy lost from the inefficiencies in fossil fuel production and aims to ...

author: WEschenbach
text:
@flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl 4/ And you're missing the main point. Even if EVs and other unknown considerations could decrease energy needs by 50% (which they can't) we'd STILL need to build one 2.1 GW nuclear plant EVERY DAY UNTIL 2050 to get to net-zero.

Never happen.

Regards,

w.

author: WEschenbach
text: @flexibledragnet @thatsamoray @GunnarLuderer @NatureEnergyJnl 3/ Finally, we have no substitute for fossil fuels for long-haul trucks, ships, and airplanes ... and the whole transport sector only uses 30% of FFs. So switching to EVs MIGHT reduce energy needs by 5% or so, NOT including the extra energy to redo our entire electrical grid.

author: WEschenbach

author: WEschenbach
text:
@TheBradSchrag @ThijssenR @crentsch Increasing clouds increases albedo AND increases atmospheric solar absorption.

And sensible and latent heat loss is a linear function of wind, so it can increase w/o surface warming.

It's a hugely complex system.

Regards,

w.

author: WEschenbach
text:
@crentsch @ThijssenR Whether or not they do that, they indeed cool the surface in dozens of ways, from increased albedo to increased wind to increased sensible and latent heat losses to cold rain/snow fall to entrained cold winds to increased ocean surface area to ... you're grasping at straws.

w.

author: PeterDClack
